elements.content: This study reports the X-ray crystal structure analysis and inclusion properties of a hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer [Ni(SCN)2(pybenH)2]∞. The crystal structures of inclusion compounds (1–18) are best described as compounds consisting of layers. The inclusion compounds are classified into two categories: compounds with channels (channel types A (1–15) and B (16 and 17)) and compounds with isolated cavities (type I (18)). Except 18, the crystal structures are similar to each other despite different molecular structures of the guests. X-ray diffraction analysis has elucidated that the interlayer separation, the position of the cavity, and the cavity volume are adjusted to the guests. In addition, the large cavity enables the guests to adjust their positions and orientations in the channels. These backgrounds cancel out the different steric requirements of the guests to a certain extent, and, as a result, the crystal structures are similar to each other. The exceptional case of 18 is due to the molecular structure and volume of pyrene being suitable to occupy the isolated cavities formed in type I.

elements.content: By replacing an isonicotinic acid dimer with a 4-(4-pyridyl)benzoic acid (pybenH) dimer, new inclusion compounds in which pybenH dimers function as bridging ligands of ca. 21 Å were obtained. Interestingly, among the 18 inclusion compounds obtained, 17 have similar crystal structures despite the different molecular structures of guests. This remarkable similarity is a rare example of solid-state inclusion compounds.

elements.content: Molecular inclusion/recognition is undoubtedly one of the most important functions in supramolecular chemistry because most of the applications of solid-state materials, such as chemical separators, catalysts, gas storages, and reaction vessels, are based on the inclusion of specific molecules in cavities and/or channels formed in the materials. Among solid-state materials, coordination polymers consisting of metal ions and organic bridging ligands have attracted considerable attention. In contrast to molecular crystals of purely organic molecules, which commonly are frustrated by an inability to predict and control molecular organization in the crystalline state, the crystal structures of coordination polymers are to some extent predictable and controllable due to high directionality of metal–ligand coordination bonding and well-defined structures of bridging ligands. For example, Zaworotko et al. reported that self-assembly of Zn2+ and 4,4′-bipyridine in the presence of SiF6 2– affords a single framework octahedral coordination polymer with square channels. Clearly, this simple but impressive structure results from the octahedral coordination geometry of the Zn2+ center and the linear bridging ligands of 4,4′-bipyridine and SiF6 2–. These attractive features make coordination polymers ideal candidates for functional materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Molecular inclusion/recognition is undoubtedly one of the most important functions in supramolecular chemistry because most of the applications of solid-state materials, such as chemical separators, catalysts, gas storages, and reaction vessels, are based on the inclusion of specific molecules in cavities and/or channels formed in the materials. Among solid-state materials, coordination polymers consisting of metal ions and organic bridging ligands have attracted considerable attention. In contrast to molecular crystals of purely organic molecules, which commonly are frustrated by an inability to predict and control molecular organization in the crystalline state, the crystal structures of coordination polymers are to some extent predictable and controllable due to high directionality of metal-ligand coordination bonding and well-defined structures of bridging ligands. For example, Zaworotko et al. reported that self-assembly of Zn2+ and 4,4'-bipyridine in the presence of SiF6 2- affords a single framework octahedral coordination polymer with square channels. Clearly, this simple but impressive structure results from the octahedral coordination geometry of the Zn2+ center and the linear bridging ligands of 4,4'-bipyridine and SiF6 2-. These attractive features make coordination polymers ideal candidates for functional materials.

elements.content: Because metal centers serve as nodes and bridging ligands as connectors, the choice of bridging ligands practically determines the structures and properties of coordination polymers. In general, bridging ligands are classified as rigid and flexible. Rigid bridging ligands, such as 4,4′-bipyridine-type ligands, are chosen for constructing coordination polymers with size and shape specificity for cavities and/or channels. Flexible bridging ligands are chosen for constructing coordination polymers with flexible frameworks. This type of coordination polymer tends to exhibit inclusion properties for various molecules, although its crystal structure tends to be affected by the guests. Note that, in most cases, the guests included in coordination polymers are usual solvent molecules and/or small aromatic molecules, irrespective of rigid or flexible bridging ligands. Coordination polymers capable of including organic molecules with various sizes and shapes in predictable manners have not been extensively investigated.

Rigid bridging ligands, such as 4,4'-bipyridine-type ligands, are chosen for constructing coordination polymers with size and shape specificity for cavities and/or channels. Flexible bridging ligands are chosen for constructing coordination polymers with flexible frameworks. This type of coordination polymer tends to exhibit inclusion properties for various molecules, although its crystal structure tends to be affected by the guests. Note that, in most cases, the guests included in coordination polymers are usual solvent molecules and/or small aromatic molecules, irrespective of rigid or flexible bridging ligands. Coordination polymers capable of including organic molecules with various sizes and shapes in predictable manners have not been extensively investigated.

elements.content: One of the final goals in the development of host–guest compounds is to create functional materials with interesting and useful properties. However, in many cases, the guests of artificial inclusion compounds are too simple and small to exhibit such properties at this stage, and overcoming this limitation is desirable. In addition, to realize such materials, their crystal structures are expected to be predictable and controllable, and thus should be insensitive to the guests. We have been interested in developing a host using hydrogen-bonded coordination polymers for the following reasons: (a) in contrast to ordinary coordination polymers where metal centers are connected by rigid bridging ligands such as 4,4′-bipyridine, hydrogen-bonded coordination polymers, whose metal centers are connected by hydrogen-bonded bridging ligands, may to some extent have flexibility on the bridging ligands; (b) such flexibility could enhance the inclusion properties for a wider range of guests without significant distortion in the structures of hydrogen-bonded coordination polymers; and (c) hydrogen-bonded bridging ligands are formed by self-assembly of components, and the synthesis of bridging ligands can be avoided.

elements.content: We have utilized a carboxylic acid dimer synthon to prepare hydrogen-bonded bridging ligands, because the carboxyl functional group exhibits a strong tendency to form highly directional and relatively strong self-complementary pairwise O–H···O hydrogen bonding (graph set R2 2(8)), and the resulting dimer can be regarded as a supramolecular analogue to the corresponding 1,4-disubstituted benzene. Because of these attractive features, this supramolecular synthon has been used in the field of crystal engineering of purely organic and organic–inorganic hybrid systems.

Because of these attractive features, this supramolecular synthon has been used in the field of crystal engineering of purely organic and organic-inorganic hybrid systems.

elements.content: Our strategy has an advantage of easy preparation of long bridging ligands from short monodentate ligands. For example, we have recently reported a series of inclusion compounds, [Ni(SCN)2(isoH)2]·(guest) x , where isoH is isonicotinic acid (4-pyridinecarboxylic acid) and guest represents aromatic molecules. Their crystal structures are best described as those consisting of layers of [Ni(SCN)2(isoH)2]∞ (Figure ). In the layer, isoH ligands coordinated to Ni2+ ions of the adjacent 1D coordination polymers form centrosymmetric carboxylic acid dimers (isoH dimers). The resulting dimers function as bridging ligands with Npyridyl/Npyridyl separation of ca. 12 Å. The isoH dimer is apparently a supramolecular analogue to 4,4′-bipyridine-type unimolecular bridging ligands, such as 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene. In the layer, the space surrounded by two isoH dimers and four μ-1,3-SCN ligands functions as a cavity for the aromatic guests. In particular, for structural extension, we have demonstrated that by exchanging the isoH dimer for a longer pyridine carboxylic acid dimer, such as a trans-3-(4-pyridyl)acrylic acid (acrylH) dimer, the cavity can be expanded without distortion in the structure of the coordination polymer and without causing framework interpenetration. This exchangeability is one of the important features of the hydrogen-bonded coordination polymers exploited by our group.
elements.clean_text: Our strategy has an advantage of easy preparation of long bridging ligands from short monodentate ligands. For example, we have recently reported a series of inclusion compounds, [Ni(SCN)2(isoH)2]⋅(guest) x , where isoH is isonicotinic acid (4-pyridinecarboxylic acid) and guest represents aromatic molecules. Their crystal structures are best described as those consisting of layers of [Ni(SCN)2(isoH)2]∞ (Figure ). In the layer, isoH ligands coordinated to Ni2+ ions of the adjacent 1D coordination polymers form centrosymmetric carboxylic acid dimers (isoH dimers). The resulting dimers function as bridging ligands with Npyridyl/Npyridyl separation of ca. 12 Å. The isoH dimer is apparently a supramolecular analogue to 4,4'-bipyridine-type unimolecular bridging ligands, such as 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene. In the layer, the space surrounded by two isoH dimers and four μ-1,3-SCN ligands functions as a cavity for the aromatic guests. In particular, for structural extension, we have demonstrated that by exchanging the isoH dimer for a longer pyridine carboxylic acid dimer, such as a trans-3-(4-pyridyl)acrylic acid (acrylH) dimer, the cavity can be expanded without distortion in the structure of the coordination polymer and without causing framework interpenetration. This exchangeability is one of the important features of the hydrogen-bonded coordination polymers exploited by our group.

elements.content: Although the isoH system can include various aromatic molecules, the high dependence of the crystal structure, in particular the stacking manner of layers, on the guests is a drawback for predicting crystal structures. One reason for this is that the molecular structure and volume of the guests are suitable to occupy isolated cavities formed in the inclusion compounds. In addition, the isoH system inevitably restricts the size of the guests within the length of the isoH dimer. We have assumed that the expansion of the cavity not only reduces the high dependence but also enables the new host system to include aromatic molecules that cannot be included in the isoH system. These factors have led us to employ a 4-(4-pyridyl)benzoic acid (pybenH) ligand as a component of the hydrogen-bonded bridging ligand (Scheme ).

elements.content: This study reports the X-ray crystal structure analysis and inclusion properties of a hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer [Ni(SCN)2(pybenH)2]∞ (pybenH system). We have revealed that the pybenH system exhibits excellent inclusion properties for various aromatic molecules including small molecules, such as naphthalene, and large ones, such as coronene. X-ray crystal structure analysis of 15 inclusion compounds and three previously reported inclusion compounds have demonstrated that most of the inclusion compounds form similar crystal structures despite different molecular structures of the guests. This remarkable similarity is a unique property of the pybenH system. The origin of the inclusion properties, the relationship between the crystal structures and the guests, and the role of the guest in the formation of the hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer are described. In addition, for quantitative analysis of intermolecular contacts between the guest and the surrounding molecules, the Hirshfeld surface analysis of six inclusion compounds has been carried out.

Experimental Section

General

All chemicals and solvents were purchased from Kanto Chemical Co., Ltd., Wako Pure Chemical Co., Ltd., and Tokyo Kasei Kogyo Co., Ltd., and were used as received without further purification. Infrared (IR) spectrum was recorded on a JASCO FT/IR-350 spectrometer at room temperature.

elements.content: Synthetic procedure of the inclusion compounds is similar to that reported previously. To a methanol solution (200 mL) in which NiCl2·6H2O (0.18 g, 0.76 mmol) was suspended was added KSCN (0.15 g, 1.54 mmol) with vigorous stirring. After the precipitated KCl was filtered off, pybenH (0.30 g, 1.51 mmol) was dissolved. The solution was left for 24 h at room temperature, and 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl was then added to the solution. Green crystals of inclusion compound 1 were obtained after slow evaporation of the solvent over a period of a week at room temperature. The crystals are insoluble in common organic solvents, such as dichloromethane, acetone, and hexane, but soluble in hot methanol, DMF, and DMSO.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthetic procedure of the inclusion compounds is similar to that reported previously. To a methanol solution (200 mL) in which NiCl2⋅6H2O (0.18 g, 0.76 mmol) was suspended was added KSCN (0.15 g, 1.54 mmol) with vigorous stirring. After the precipitated KCl was filtered off, pybenH (0.30 g, 1.51 mmol) was dissolved. The solution was left for 24 h at room temperature, and 4,4'-dibromobiphenyl was then added to the solution. Green crystals of inclusion compound 1 were obtained after slow evaporation of the solvent over a period of a week at room temperature. The crystals are insoluble in common organic solvents, such as dichloromethane, acetone, and hexane, but soluble in hot methanol, DMF, and DMSO.

elements.content: Except for the void space per unit cell (V void), all geometrical calculations were carried out using the SHELXL-97 and the Mercury 2.4.5 programs. The void space per unit cell (V void) was calculated using the PLATON program. Except for 9,10-dichloroanthracene and triphenylene, van der Waals (vdW) volume of the aromatic molecules was calculated using the X-ray structural data. The vdW volumes of 9,10-dichloroanthracene and triphenylene were calculated using their energy-minimized structures (PM6, MOPAC 7 program). To clarify the relative positions between the pybenH dimer and the guest, the following two parameters, l CC and θ, were also calculated. As shown in Figure a, l CC is the distance between the centroids of the aromatic planes, and the slip angle θ is the angle between the centroid vector and the mean plane of the guest. The mean π···π distance, l ππ, is defined as a mean distance between a carbon atom of the aromatic ring and a mean plane of the aromatic ring (Figure b). For estimating the deviation from the planarity of the R2 2(8) O–H···O hydrogen bonding, θCOOH was calculated (Figure c). The θCOOH is defined as the dihedral angle between the mean planes of the carboxyl functional group.
elements.clean_text:
Geometric Calculations

Except for the void space per unit cell (V void), all geometrical calculations were carried out using the SHELXL-97 and the Mercury 2.4.5 programs. The void space per unit cell (V void) was calculated using the PLATON program. Except for 9,10-dichloroanthracene and triphenylene, van der Waals (vdW) volume of the aromatic molecules was calculated using the X-ray structural data. The vdW volumes of 9,10-dichloroanthracene and triphenylene were calculated using their energy-minimized structures (PM6, MOPAC 7 program). To clarify the relative positions between the pybenH dimer and the guest, the following two parameters, l CC and θ, were also calculated. As shown in Figure a, l CC is the distance between the centroids of the aromatic planes, and the slip angle θ is the angle between the centroid vector and the mean plane of the guest. The mean π⋅⋅⋅π distance, l ππ, is defined as a mean distance between a carbon atom of the aromatic ring and a mean plane of the aromatic ring (Figure b). For estimating the deviation from the planarity of the R2 2(8) O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding, θCOOH was calculated (Figure c). The θCOOH is defined as the dihedral angle between the mean planes of the carboxyl functional group.

X-ray crystallographic data for 1–14 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate area detector using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 153 K. X-ray crystallographic data for 19 were collected at 293 K, because the structural data of the isoH system were collected at 293 K. X-ray crystallographic data for 15 were collected on a Rigaku Saturn-CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 103 K. Crystallographic parameters are listed in Table . The crystal structures were solved by direct method using the SHELXS-97 program and were refined by the successive differential Fourier syntheses and full-matrix least-squares procedure using the SHELXL-97 program. Anisotropic thermal factors were applied to all non-hydrogen atoms except the disordered atoms. All hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. The hydrogen atom of the carboxyl functional group of the pybenH ligand was attached to one of the two oxygen atoms that has a longer C–O bond length (HFIX 147, SHELXL-97). In 3 and 13, EADP restraint (SHELXL-97) was applied to the guests due to the low quality of the diffraction data. In 4, the position of the hydrogen atom of the oxime functional group was estimated on the basis of the electron density map (HFIX 147, SHELXL-97). In 15, the coronene guest might be disordered at two positions. In 8 and 12, the positions of the guests could not be determined. Thus, the diffuse electron density arising from the guests was treated with SQUEEZE routine within the PLATON software package. The final d calc, μ, and formula weight reflect known contents only. Computer graphics of the crystal structures were portrayed with the Mercury 2.4.5 program.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Determination

X-ray crystallographic data for 1-14 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate area detector using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 153 K. X-ray crystallographic data for 19 were collected at 293 K, because the structural data of the isoH system were collected at 293 K. X-ray crystallographic data for 15 were collected on a Rigaku Saturn-CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 103 K. Crystallographic parameters are listed in Table . The crystal structures were solved by direct method using the SHELXS-97 program and were refined by the successive differential Fourier syntheses and full-matrix least-squares procedure using the SHELXL-97 program. Anisotropic thermal factors were applied to all non-hydrogen atoms except the disordered atoms. All hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. The hydrogen atom of the carboxyl functional group of the pybenH ligand was attached to one of the two oxygen atoms that has a longer C-O bond length (HFIX 147, SHELXL-97). In 3 and 13, EADP restraint (SHELXL-97) was applied to the guests due to the low quality of the diffraction data. In 4, the position of the hydrogen atom of the oxime functional group was estimated on the basis of the electron density map (HFIX 147, SHELXL-97). In 15, the coronene guest might be disordered at two positions. In 8 and 12, the positions of the guests could not be determined. Thus, the diffuse electron density arising from the guests was treated with SQUEEZE routine within the PLATON software package. The final d calc, μ, and formula weight reflect known contents only. Computer graphics of the crystal structures were portrayed with the Mercury 2.4.5 program.

Results

Guests

The following 15 aromatic molecules were employed: 4,4'-dibromobiphenyl (1), biphenyl (2), diphenylacetylene (3), 9-fluorenone oxime (4), phenanthrene (5), anthracene (6), 9,10-dihydroanthracene (7), 9,10-dichloroanthracene (8), anthraquinone (9), trans-stilbene (10), azobenzene (11), triphenylene (12), benz[a]anthracene (13), chrysene (14), and coronene (15) (Figure ). These aromatic molecules were chosen for investigating (a) the inclusion properties of the pybenH system and (b) the effect of the molecule structures of the guests on the resulting crystal structures.

elements.content: Single crystals of an inclusion compound were obtained from a methanol solution containing Ni2+, SCN–, pybenH, and a guest by slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature. The color of the crystals is generally bluish-green with some exceptions, such as brownish-green (11) and green (15). The photographs of the crystals of 6, 11, 14, and 15 are shown in Figure a–d, respectively.

Synthesis

Single crystals of an inclusion compound were obtained from a methanol solution containing Ni2+, SCN-, pybenH, and a guest by slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature. The color of the crystals is generally bluish-green with some exceptions, such as brownish-green (11) and green (15). The photographs of the crystals of 6, 11, 14, and 15 are shown in Figure a-d, respectively.

elements.content: Figure shows the IR spectrum of 1. The spectrum exhibits several characteristic absorption bands: broad absorption band in the range 2200–3200 cm–1 (stretching vibration of O–H···O hydrogen bonding) and strong absorption bands at 2100 cm–1 (stretching vibration of CN) and 1684 cm–1 (stretching vibration of CO). The broad absorption band demonstrates the formation of the carboxylic acid dimer. The IR spectra of 2–15 are very similar to that of 1.

IR Spectra

Figure  shows the IR spectrum of 1. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the inclusion compounds crystallize in the triclinic crystal system with space group P1̅ (No. 2). The crystal structures of 1–15 are best described as compounds consisting of layers [Ni(SCN)2(pybenH)2]∞. Except for 8 and 12, host–guest ratios ([Ni(SCN)2(pybenH)2]:guest) were determined by X-ray diffraction analysis and elemental analysis. The host–guest ratios including the previously reported three inclusion compounds (16–18) are listed in Table . The host–guest ratios are 2:1 with some exceptions, 1:1 (16 and 18) and 3:1 (15). In the cases of 8 and 12, the guests could not be located on the electron density maps, and their host–guest ratios could not be determined. The elemental analysis suggests that their host–guest ratios are in the range 2:1–3:1. The crystal structures of 1–15 are isostructural to each other with respect to the position of the host frameworks. The coordination environments around the Ni2+ centers and the R2 2(8) O–H···O hydrogen-bond distances between the pybenH ligands are very similar throughout the inclusion compounds. Detailed host–guest geometry (l CC, θ, l ππ, and etc.) is described only in the case of 1, and those of the other inclusion compounds are summarized in the .

X-ray Crystal Structures and Host-Guest Ratios

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the inclusion compounds crystallize in the triclinic crystal system with space group P1̅ (No. 2). The crystal structures of 1-15 are best described as compounds consisting of layers [Ni(SCN)2(pybenH)2]∞. Except for 8 and 12, host-guest ratios ([Ni(SCN)2(pybenH)2]:guest) were determined by X-ray diffraction analysis and elemental analysis. The host-guest ratios including the previously reported three inclusion compounds (16-18) are listed in Table . The host-guest ratios are 2:1 with some exceptions, 1:1 (16 and 18) and 3:1 (15). In the cases of 8 and 12, the guests could not be located on the electron density maps, and their host-guest ratios could not be determined. The elemental analysis suggests that their host-guest ratios are in the range 2:1-3:1. The crystal structures of 1-15 are isostructural to each other with respect to the position of the host frameworks. The coordination environments around the Ni2+ centers and the R2 2(8) O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bond distances between the pybenH ligands are very similar throughout the inclusion compounds. Detailed host-guest geometry (l CC, θ, l ππ, and etc.) is described only in the case of 1, and those of the other inclusion compounds are summarized in the .

elements.content: In the following crystal structure descriptions, axis settings are used for easy structural comparison: the 1D coordination polymer propagates along the [010] axis (1–14); Ni2+–pybenH···pybenH–Ni2+ linkages propagate along the [001] axis (1–14) or the [012] axis (16–18); and the layer spreads over the (100) plane (1–14, 16–18). In the case of 15, the 1D coordination polymer and Ni2+–pybenH···pybenH–Ni2+ linkages propagate along the [130] and the [1̅03] axes, respectively, and the layer spreads over the (31̅1) plane.

Void space per unit cells (V void) were calculated using PLATON program. The numerical value in the parentheses = V void/unit cell × 100%.

The volume of the guests (V guest) was calculated using the X-ray structure data.

Packing coefficient = {(n × V guest)/(V void)}, where n = the number of the guests per unit cell.

The host–guest ratio was estimated by elemental analysis.

The volume of the guest was calculated using energy-minimized structure of the guest (PM6, MOPAC 7).

The PC could not be calculated, as the host–guest ratio could not be determined.

The asymmetric unit contains one Ni2+ ion, two SCN–, two pybenH ligands, and one 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl guest that is disordered over two positions. The Ni2+ ion is six-coordinated to four nitrogen atoms from two pybenH ligands and two μ-1,3-SCN ligands, and to two sulfur atoms from two μ-1,3-SCN ligands in distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Selected bond lengths and angles around the Ni2+ center are listed in Table . The coordination environment is very similar to those of the isoH system. Figure a shows the 1D coordination polymer formed in 1. Each Ni2+ ion is connected to the adjacent Ni2+ ions by two μ-1,3-SCN ligands with the Ni2+/Ni2+ separation of 5.570(2) Å. The [−Ni–(SCN)2−]∞ chain has a wavy structure due to the zigzag arrangement of the Ni2+ ions along the [010] axis. Each pybenH ligand forms R2 2(8) hydrogen bonding with the pybenH ligand of the adjacent 1D coordination polymer. The hydrogen-bond distances are 2.605(8) Å (O11···O31) and 2.628(4) Å (O12···O32), indicating moderate hydrogen bonding. The pybenH dimers function as long bridging ligands and connect between Ni2+ ions with the Ni2+/Ni2+ separation of 25.047(7) Å, which gives the layer [Ni(SCN)2(pybenH)2]∞ (Npyridyl/Npyridyl separation is 20.822(7) Å). The layers are stacked along the [100] axis to form 1 (Figure a). The layer has rectangular cavities surrounded by two pybenH dimers and four μ-1,3-SCN ligands with dimensions of ca. 21 (the distance between the nitrogen atoms of the pybenH dimer) × 7 Å2 (the distance between the mean planes defined by the carboxyl functional group of the pybenH ligand). The interlayer connection of the cavities along the [100] axis gives channels penetrating through the crystal.

elements.content: In the channels, the 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl guests exist between the layers and are arranged one-dimensionally. The benzene rings of the guest are not coplanar but are twisted (19.8°) due to steric repulsion between the α-hydrogen atoms. The long axis of the guest, which penetrates the two bromine atoms, is parallel to the [001] axis. The benzene ring A of the guest is almost parallel (4.6°) to the benzene ring BA of the pybenH ligand, and l CC, l ππ, and θ are 3.675(7) Å, 3.28 Å, and 64.2°, respectively, whereas the benzene ring B of the guest is not parallel (20.3°) to the benzene ring BB of the pybenH ligand, and l CC, l ππ, and θ are 4.010(7) Å, 3.61 Å, and 74.1°, respectively (Figure a, inset).

The asymmetric unit contains one Ni2+ ion, two SCN–, two pybenH ligands, and one biphenyl guest that is disordered over two positions. One of the two pybenH ligands is disordered over two positions with the site occupancy factor (sof) = 0.502(6):0.498(6). The benzene rings of the guest are not coplanar but are twisted (24.2°) due to steric repulsion between the α-hydrogen atoms. In the channels, the guests are arranged one-dimensionally (Figure b). Unlike the 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl guest in 1, the guests are located at the center of the cavity.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit contains one Ni2+ ion, two SCN–, two pybenH ligands, and one 9-fluorenone oxime guest that lies on a center of inversion and is disordered over two positions. The guests are located at the center of the cavity and are arranged one-dimensionally (Figure d). Because of the disorder of the guest, there are two possible arrays of the guests in the channels: (a) the R2 2(6) O–H···N hydrogen-bonded dimers, which are a usual structure of ketoximes, are arranged one-dimensionally (Figure a); and (b) the 9-fluorenone oxime guests are arranged one-dimensionally with a head-to-tail manner, and the adjacent guests are connected by C–H···O hydrogen bonding (Figure b). On the basis of the position of the hydrogen atom of the oxime functional group, which was estimated by the electron density map, the head-to-tail manner is a possible array. The O···O distance between the oxime functional group and the carboxyl functional group is too long (>3.6 Å) to form hydrogen bonding.

The guests are disordered over two positions with the sof = 0.67(2):0.33(2), resulting probably from pedal-like motion of the ethylene bridge, as reported by Harada et al. The guests are located at the center of the cavity and are arranged one-dimensionally (Figure c).

elements.content: The crystal structures of 16–18 were reported previously. For comparison with those of 1–15, their crystal structures are shown in Figure a–c, respectively. The crystal structures of 16 and 17 are isostructural to each other with respect to the position of the frameworks. Although the structures of the layers of 16 and 17 and their crystal structures are similar to those of 1–15, the position of the cavity (Figure b) and the cavity volume (see the section of cavity volume and pybenH dimer) are different. The interlayer connection of the cavities along the [100] axis gives the channels penetrating through the crystals. In 16, the two naphthalene guests are included in the cavity, and each guest is disordered over two positions with the sof = 0.509(3):0.491(3) (disorder A and disorder B and only disorder A is shown in Figure a). In 17, the dibenz[a,h]anthracene guest penetrates three cavities. Although the structure of the layer of 18 is very similar to those of 16 and 17, the stacking manner of layers is different (see the section ofn classification). Two pyrene guests are included in the cavity. The pyrene guest and the pybenH dimer form C–H···O hydrogen bonding with the C–H···O distances of 2.65(1) and 2.55(1) Å.

Crystal Structures of 16-18 

The crystal structures of 16-18 were reported previously. For comparison with those of 1-15, their crystal structures are shown in Figure a-c, respectively. The crystal structures of 16 and 17 are isostructural to each other with respect to the position of the frameworks. Although the structures of the layers of 16 and 17 and their crystal structures are similar to those of 1-15, the position of the cavity (Figure b) and the cavity volume (see the section of cavity volume and pybenH dimer) are different. In 16, the two naphthalene guests are included in the cavity, and each guest is disordered over two positions with the sof = 0.509(3):0.491(3) (disorder A and disorder B and only disorder A is shown in Figure a). In 17, the dibenz[a,h]anthracene guest penetrates three cavities. Although the structure of the layer of 18 is very similar to those of 16 and 17, the stacking manner of layers is different (see the section ofn classification). elements.content: To elucidate the role of the guest on the formation of the hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer, we have tried to obtain a guest-free compound. However, crystallization without the guest afforded only crystals of the pybenH ligand. Therefore, we have prepared a guest-free compound of the isoH system (19). Although the isoH ligand is shorter than the pybenH ligand, their linear structures are similar, and the crystal structure of 19 should give several pieces of information on the role of the guest. Crystals of 19 were obtained from an acetonitrile solution containing Ni2+, SCN–, and isoH by slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallization without the Guest

To elucidate the role of the guest on the formation of the hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer, we have tried to obtain a guest-free compound. However, crystallization without the guest afforded only crystals of the pybenH ligand. Therefore, we have prepared a guest-free compound of the isoH system (19). Although the isoH ligand is shorter than the pybenH ligand, their linear structures are similar, and the crystal structure of 19 should give several pieces of information on the role of the guest. Crystals of 19 were obtained from an acetonitrile solution containing Ni2+, SCN-, and isoH by slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature.

elements.content: Guest-free compound 19 belongs to the orthorhombic crystal system with space group Pbca (No. 61). The asymmetric unit contains one Ni2+ ion, two SCN–, two isoH ligands, one N-protonated isonicotinate (Hiso), and two molecules of acetonitrile. Crystal structure viewed along the [100] axis is shown in Figure a. Although 1D coordination polymers [Ni(SCN)2(isoH)2]∞ are formed along the [100] axis, no R2 2(8) carboxylic acid dimer is formed. Two adjacent isoH ligands form O–H···O hydrogen bonding with Hiso (Figure b). Small cavities remain between the μ-1,3-SCN ligands and Hiso, and each cavity traps two molecules of acetonitrile by (Hiso) N–H···N (acetonitrile) hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction analyses of the 15 inclusion compounds (1–15) and the three previously reported inclusion compounds (16–18) demonstrate that the pybenH system exhibits excellent inclusion properties for aromatic molecules. The expansion of the cavity improved the inclusion properties for large aromatic molecules. For example, coronene, which cannot be included in the isoH system due to its molecular size, was included in the pybenH system. In addition, the expansion also increased the number of guests per cavity. The cavities of the isoH and the acrylH systems include one molecule of naphthalene and pyrene, respectively, whereas the pybenH system includes two molecules of naphthalene (Figure a) and pyrene (Figure c) per cavity. These situations, close proximity of the two guests in the cavity, are ideal for conducting a reaction within the crystal. This possibility is now under investigation. On the other hand, no solvent molecule was included. This results from the fact that (a) except for 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl, naphthalene, and pyrene, the guests are located at the center of the cavity, which is a hydrophilic region, and they prevent the solvent molecule from accessing the carboxyl functional groups, and (b) the guests occupy the channels and no solvent-accessible space remains. In addition, the hydrophobic nature of the guests may also prevent the inclusion of the solvent molecule.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Inclusion Properties

X-ray diffraction analyses of the 15 inclusion compounds (1-15) and the three previously reported inclusion compounds (16-18) demonstrate that the pybenH system exhibits excellent inclusion properties for aromatic molecules. The expansion of the cavity improved the inclusion properties for large aromatic molecules. For example, coronene, which cannot be included in the isoH system due to its molecular size, was included in the pybenH system. In addition, the expansion also increased the number of guests per cavity. The cavities of the isoH and the acrylH systems include one molecule of naphthalene and pyrene, respectively, whereas the pybenH system includes two molecules of naphthalene (Figure a) and pyrene (Figure c) per cavity. These situations, close proximity of the two guests in the cavity, are ideal for conducting a reaction within the crystal. This possibility is now under investigation. On the other hand, no solvent molecule was included. This results from the fact that (a) except for 4,4'-dibromobiphenyl, naphthalene, and pyrene, the guests are located at the center of the cavity, which is a hydrophilic region, and they prevent the solvent molecule from accessing the carboxyl functional groups, and (b) the guests occupy the channels and no solvent-accessible space remains. In addition, the hydrophobic nature of the guests may also prevent the inclusion of the solvent molecule.

elements.content: Crystallization without the guest did not afford crystals of a guest-free compound. This indicates that the guests are indispensable for the formation of the hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer. This is supported by the crystal structure of 19 where no layer is formed without the guests (aromatic molecules). Most likely, in the pybenH system (and the isoH system), the guests serve as a template of the layers.
elements.clean_text:
Template

Crystallization without the guest did not afford crystals of a guest-free compound. This indicates that the guests are indispensable for the formation of the hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer. This is supported by the crystal structure of 19 where no layer is formed without the guests (aromatic molecules). Most likely, in the pybenH system (and the isoH system), the guests serve as a template of the layers.

elements.content: Except for 18, the stacking manner of layers in all inclusion compounds is considerably similar. Figure a and b shows the X-ray crystal structures of 1 and 18 viewed along the [001] and [012] axes, respectively, and Figure c and d shows schematic representations of the stacking manner of the layers of 1–17 and 18, respectively. Focusing on the region between the adjacent layers (interlayer region) is helpful for understanding the differences in the stacking manner. In 1–17, both sides of the interlayer regions are opened to the adjacent cavities so that the interlayer region connects the cavities to form the channel penetrating through the crystal. In contrast, in 18, only one side of the interlayer region is opened to the cavity, and the opposite side is closed to the cavity of the adjacent layer so that each cavity is isolated (isolated cavity) and channel-like space is not formed. This type of difference is found in the isoH system. In that system, we classified 21 inclusion compounds into four categories according to the stacking manner of layers: type m (m = I, II, III) and channel type. Type m has isolated cavities that consist of m × cavity and (m – 1) × interlayer region, whereas channel type has channels penetrating through the crystal. Considering this classification and the different positions of the cavities in the layers (Figure a and b), 1–15 are channel type A, 16 and 17 are channel type B, and 18 is type I (Table ).

There are three crystallographically independent pybenH dimers.

The benzene ring of the pybenH ligand is disordered over two positions.

Among the 18 inclusion compounds, 17 compounds (94%) have channels, and 15 of those (88%) belong to channel type A. Therefore, it can be concluded that channel type A is the representative crystal structure of the pybenH system. These results demonstrate that the expansion of the cavity successfully reduces the diversity of the crystal structures. This sharply contrasts the isoH system in which the stacking manner of layers highly depends on the guests, as mentioned earlier. For example, anthraquinone and benz[a]anthracene form type I, azobenzene and 9,10-dihydroanthracene form type II, and triphenylene forms type III.

elements.content: The calculated V void values of 1–18 are listed in Table . The V void of channel type A is in the range 280–374 Å3 (19%–25% of the unit cell) and is smaller than the V void of channel type B, which is in the range 435–456 Å3 (28%–29% of the unit cell). (For 15, V void/3 ≈ 333 Å3.) In channel type B, the larger void space results primary from the large cavity volume as compared to that of channel type A (vide infra) and secondary from the longer interlayer separation (1–15, 5.40–5.56 Å; 16 and 17, 5.72–5.80 Å). (The interlayer separation is defined as the mean distance between a mean plane of the Ni2+ ions of a layer and an Ni2+ ion of the adjacent layer.) The V void of type I is 656 Å3 (38% of the unit cell). The largest V void results from the longest interlayer separation (6.61 Å) and the large cavity volume as compared to that of channel type A.

elements.content: Figure a and c shows the cavities formed in channel types A and B, respectively. (The cavity of type I is similar to that of channel type B and is not shown.) In channel type A, one of the two pyridine rings, indicated with arrows, is largely twisted with respect to the benzene rings (θ1 in Table ), and the hydrogen atoms of the pyridine rings are pointed to the cavity, resulting in a decrease in the cavity volume (see also Figure a). On the other hand, in channel type B and type I, although the pyridine rings are twisted (θ1 in Table ), no such reduction occurred (see also Figure b). As a result, the guest can access the entire area of the cavity. The center of the pybenH dimer is not planar but twisted (θCOOH in Table ). As compared to the θCOOH of channel type A (8(1)°–18.2(6)°), the θCOOH values of channel type B and type I are small (4(1)°–5.1(4)°). Most likely, this results from the different orientation of the pyridine rings. Interestingly, the Npyridyl/Npyridyl separation is not constant but varies in the range 20.72(2)–21.03(2) Å (average 20.88 Å). These parameters demonstrate that, by varying the conformation of the pybenH dimer, the pybenH system adjusts the cavity volume to the guest.

elements.content: The molecular structures of the guests that form channel type A are different. For example, coronene is circular and has a large aromatic surface, diphenylacetylene is linear, and 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl and biphenyl are twisted. However, despite these differences, they form the same structural type. Similarly, naphthalene and dibenz[a,h]anthracene have different molecular structures but form channel type B. The relationship between the guest and the resulting structural type can be understood by packing coefficients (PCs). PC is defined as PC = {(n × V guest)/(V cavity)} × 100 (%), where n is the number of guests included in the cavity, V guest is the volume of a guest, and V cavity is the volume of the cavity. In this work, V cavity is the void space per unit cell (V void). PC relies on steric complementation between host cavities and guest components as a result of the key and lock mechanism in molecular recognition. Rebek Jr. et al. reported that the PC of 55 ± 9% gives the best binding constants for the resulting host–guest complexes in solutions. The concept of PC also holds for the inclusion compounds as reported by Miyata et al. They confirmed that the PC values lie in the range 55%–70%.
elements.clean_text:
Guest-Structural Type Relationship and Rebek's Packing Coefficients

The molecular structures of the guests that form channel type A are different. For example, coronene is circular and has a large aromatic surface, diphenylacetylene is linear, and 4,4'-dibromobiphenyl and biphenyl are twisted. However, despite these differences, they form the same structural type. Similarly, naphthalene and dibenz[a,h]anthracene have different molecular structures but form channel type B. The relationship between the guest and the resulting structural type can be understood by packing coefficients (PCs). PC is defined as PC = {(n × V guest)/(V cavity)} × 100 (%), where n is the number of guests included in the cavity, V guest is the volume of a guest, and V cavity is the volume of the cavity. In this work, V cavity is the void space per unit cell (V void). PC relies on steric complementation between host cavities and guest components as a result of the key and lock mechanism in molecular recognition. Rebek Jr. et al. reported that the PC of 55 ± 9% gives the best binding constants for the resulting host-guest complexes in solutions. The concept of PC also holds for the inclusion compounds as reported by Miyata et al. They confirmed that the PC values lie in the range 55%-70%.

elements.content: Table shows the calculated PCs for the guests in the respective inclusion compounds except 8 and 12. In all cases, the PCs lie within suitable values (48%–61%). The guests with V guest in the range 149–214 Å3 form channel type A. The difference in V guest between chrysene and biphenyl is 65 Å3, and that in V void between 13 and 3 is 94 Å3, whereas the difference in the interlayer separations is within 5.40–5.56 Å throughout 1–15. This indicates that channel type A can adjust the cavity volume to the guests to a relatively large extent. Naphthalene (111 Å3 × 2 = 222 Å3) and dibenz[a,h]anthracene (250 Å3), whose V guest values are higher than those of the guests that form channel type A, form channel type B. This is consistent with the cavity volume of channel type B being larger than that of channel type A. This V guest–structural type relationship indicates that V guest is the primary factor for determining the structural type. In the case of coronene, however, its molecular structure also affects the crystal packing. Although the V guest of coronene (259 Å3) is almost the same as that of dibenz[a,h]anthracene, it formed channel type A. This is due to the circular structure of coronene. Channel type A, which has small cavities as compared to channel type B, is more suitable for coronene to occupy the channel (Figure b and d).

elements.content: Pyrene formed type I, although its V guest (187 Å3) is similar to that of 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl (182 Å3) and anthraquinone (183 Å3). This is due to the molecular structure and volume of pyrene being suitable to occupy the isolated cavity formed in Type I (Figure e). In addition, the C–H···O hydrogen bonding may be also one of the reasons that pyrene selects Type I. Similar results were obtained in the isoH system. For example, diphenylbutadiyne forms type II, because two molecules of diphenylbutadiyne are suitable to occupy the isolated cavity of type II.

elements.content: Although there are some differences between the channel types A and B, their crystal structures are similar to each other, as mentioned earlier. From the crystal structures and the PCs of 1–17, the interlayer separation, the position of the cavity, and the cavity volume are adjusted to the guests for forming close-packed structures, that is, to realize suitable PCs. In addition, the large cavity enables the guests to adjust their positions and orientations in the channel. These backgrounds cancel out the different steric requirements of the guests to a certain extent, and, as a result, their crystal structures are similar to each other. The exceptional case of 18 implies that the expansion of the cavity makes it difficult for the guests to occupy the isolated cavities of type m and, as a result, most aromatic molecules form channel type A or B.

elements.content: Assuming that the host–guest ratios of 8 and 12 are 2:1, their PCs are 61.1% and 69.5%, respectively. Considering the PCs of the other inclusion compounds, the host–guest ratio of 8 is expected to be close to 2:1, whereas that of 12 is smaller than 2:1. This is consistent with their elemental analysis. In the case of 8, the calculated C, H, N % assuming the 2:1 host–guest ratio is C 56.88%, H 3.18%, N 8.04%, and that observed is C 56.84%, H 3.37%, N 8.22%. In the case of 12, although calculated C, H, N % assuming the 2:1 host–guest ratio is C 61.15%, H 3.52%, N 8.15%, that observed is C 59.42%, H 3.65%, N 8.43%.

elements.content: In most cases, the guests and the benzene ring of the pybenH ligands are almost parallel, indicative of π···π interaction between them (host–guest geometry in the ). In the cases of 10, 13, 14, and 16–18, the pyridine rings also participate in the π···π interaction. This is most likely due to the relatively long molecular structures of the guests (10, 13, 14, and 17) and/or the large cavity volume as compared to that of channel type A (16–18), which enables the guests to access the pyridine rings. Except for 1 and 16, the carboxyl functional groups lie on the guests, and, in some cases, the distances between the sp2 carbon atom of the carboxyl functional group and the mean plane of the guest are shorter than the vdW separation. Interestingly, short (guest) H···S (SCN–) contacts exist, and, in some cases, the distances are almost equal to or shorter than the vdW separation. These results indicate that not only π···π interaction but also these short contacts participate in the host–guest interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Host-Guest Interactions

In most cases, the guests and the benzene ring of the pybenH ligands are almost parallel, indicative of π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between them (host-guest geometry in the ). In the cases of 10, 13, 14, and 16-18, the pyridine rings also participate in the π⋅⋅⋅π interaction. This is most likely due to the relatively long molecular structures of the guests (10, 13, 14, and 17) and/or the large cavity volume as compared to that of channel type A (16-18), which enables the guests to access the pyridine rings. Except for 1 and 16, the carboxyl functional groups lie on the guests, and, in some cases, the distances between the sp2 carbon atom of the carboxyl functional group and the mean plane of the guest are shorter than the vdW separation. Interestingly, short (guest) H⋅⋅⋅S (SCN-) contacts exist, and, in some cases, the distances are almost equal to or shorter than the vdW separation. These results indicate that not only π⋅⋅⋅π interaction but also these short contacts participate in the host-guest interaction.

elements.content: To investigate the detailed intermolecular contacts, we have carried out the Hirshfeld surface analysis of the six guests (anthracene (6), 9,10-dihydroanthracene (7), chrysene (14), coronene (15), dibenz[a,h]anthracene (17), and pyrene (18)) using the CrystalExplorer ver. 2.1 program. In these inclusion compounds, no structural disorder was found in the guests, as mentioned earlier. The Hirshfeld surface and a fingerprint plot generated from that are a valuable tool for analyzing and comparing intermolecular interactions. In addition, the fingerprint plot can be decomposed to highlight particular atom pair close contact. A 3D isosurface picture of the Hirshfeld surface mapped with d norm of the chrysene guest in 14 and the corresponding decomposed fingerprint plots constructed by plotting d e against d i are shown in Figure a–h. The 3D isosurface pictures and the corresponding decomposed fingerprint plots of the other five guests are shown in Figures S1–S5 in the . Parameters d e and d i are defined by the distances external and internal to the Hirshfeld surface, respectively, and parameter d norm is a normalized contact distance defined by d norm = (d i – r i vdW)/r i vdW + (d e – r e vdW)/r e vdW, where r vdW is the vdW radius of the appropriate atom internal or external to the surface. Parameter d norm is negative where contacts shorter than vdW separation occur, and positive for contacts greater than vdW separations, and is displayed using a red–white–blue color scheme, where red highlights shorter contacts, white is used for contacts around the vdW separation, and blue is for longer contacts. Detailed information of the Hirshfeld surface analysis including the parameters d e, d i, and d norm is described in the literature.

elements.content: The Hirshfeld surface analysis well reproduced the results of the X-ray crystal structure analysis and elucidated that between the guest and the surrounding molecules including the neighboring guests seven intermolecular contacts (C···C, C···H, H···H, C···O, H···S, H···O, and H···N) exist. The relative contribution to the Hirshfeld surfaces is shown in Figure . As expected, C···H and H···H contacts are dominant intermolecular contacts, and C···C contact is the next. These three contacts occupy ca. 80% of the Hirshfeld surfaces. The remaining 20% is mainly occupied by C···O (2.6%–7.9%) and H···S (3.5%–6.8%) contacts. The contributions of H···O and H···N contacts are small except for 18 where the C–H···O hydrogen bonding increases the relative contribution of H···O contacts (8.1%). The white-to-blue color on the Hirshfeld surfaces and the decomposed fingerprint plots indicate that these intermolecular contacts are around or longer than the vdW separations. However, some regions indicated by the red circles are shorter than the vdW separations, such as C···C (benzene ring), C···C (sp2(II)), and H···C (pyridine ring) contacts found in the chrysene guest as shown in Figure a. The guests that form channel type A or B exhibit similar relative contributions, although there are some exceptions originating from the different molecular structures of the guests. That is, small and large contributions of C···C (6.2%) and H···H (44.0%) contacts, respectively, of the 9,10-dihydroanthracene guest result from its narrow aromatic surfaces, and the large contribution of C···C contact (14.1%) of the coronene guest results from its large aromatic surface. On the other hand, the pyrene guest, that is, type I, exhibits different tendency: the large contributions of C···C (15.6%) and H···H (46.1%) contacts and small contribution of C···H contact (21.7%). This results partly from the pyrene guest included in the isolated cavity and partly from the benzene rings of the pybenH ligands that lie on the top and bottom of the guest (host–guest geometry in the ). The former situation increases the H···H and H···O contacts, and the latter situation increases C···C contact but decreases C···H contact.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure analyses of 15 inclusion compounds (1–15) and the three previously reported inclusion compounds (16–18) have demonstrated that the pybenH system exhibits excellent inclusion properties for various aromatic molecules. The expansion of the cavity enables the new host system to include large aromatic molecules that cannot be included in the isoH system. The guests serve as a template for the formation of the hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer, as no guest-free compound in the pybenH system was formed. This is supported by the guest-free compound in the isoH system (19) where no layer is formed without planar aromatic molecules. The inclusion compounds are classified into two categories: compounds with channels penetrating through the crystal (channel types A (1–15) and B (16 and 17)) and compounds with isolated cavities (type I (18)). Except for 18, the crystal structures of the inclusion compounds are similar to each other. This remarkable similarity is a unique property of the pybenH system and sharply contrasts the previously reported isoH system in which the crystal structures highly depend on the guests. X-ray crystal structure analysis has demonstrated that the inclusion compounds adjust interlayer separation, the position of the cavities, and the cavity volume. In addition, the large cavity as compared to the cavity of the isoH system enables the guests to adjust their positions and orientations within the channel. These backgrounds cancel out the different steric requirements of the guests to a certain extent, and, as a result, the crystal structures of the inclusion compounds are similar despite different molecular structures of the guests. The exceptional case of 18 is due to its molecular structure and volume being suitable to occupy the isolated cavities formed in type I. In other words, this exceptional case indicates that the expansion of the cavity makes it difficult for the guests to occupy isolated cavities of type m and consequently reduces the diversity of the crystal structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

X-ray crystal structure analyses of 15 inclusion compounds (1-15) and the three previously reported inclusion compounds (16-18) have demonstrated that the pybenH system exhibits excellent inclusion properties for various aromatic molecules. The expansion of the cavity enables the new host system to include large aromatic molecules that cannot be included in the isoH system. The guests serve as a template for the formation of the hydrogen-bonded coordination polymer, as no guest-free compound in the pybenH system was formed. This is supported by the guest-free compound in the isoH system (19) where no layer is formed without planar aromatic molecules. The inclusion compounds are classified into two categories: compounds with channels penetrating through the crystal (channel types A (1-15) and B (16 and 17)) and compounds with isolated cavities (type I (18)). Except for 18, the crystal structures of the inclusion compounds are similar to each other. This remarkable similarity is a unique property of the pybenH system and sharply contrasts the previously reported isoH system in which the crystal structures highly depend on the guests. X-ray crystal structure analysis has demonstrated that the inclusion compounds adjust interlayer separation, the position of the cavities, and the cavity volume. In addition, the large cavity as compared to the cavity of the isoH system enables the guests to adjust their positions and orientations within the channel. These backgrounds cancel out the different steric requirements of the guests to a certain extent, and, as a result, the crystal structures of the inclusion compounds are similar despite different molecular structures of the guests. The exceptional case of 18 is due to its molecular structure and volume being suitable to occupy the isolated cavities formed in type I. In other words, this exceptional case indicates that the expansion of the cavity makes it difficult for the guests to occupy isolated cavities of type m and consequently reduces the diversity of the crystal structures.

elements.content: Note that PCs of the solid-state inclusion compounds have been calculated mainly for small organic molecules, and there are few examples of the systematic investigation of the relationship between the crystal structures of the inclusion compounds and the guests with various molecular structures, to the best of our knowledge. The present study has confirmed that the concept of PC is considerably useful for understanding the relationship between the crystal structures of the inclusion compounds and the molecular structures of the guests.

elements.content: Because of the inclusion properties and crystal structures of the pybenH system, it is expected that the pybenH system may include other aromatic molecules and one-dimensionally arrange these guests. Additionally, unlike the crystals of the guests, the aromatic planes of the guests in the inclusion compounds are always parallel. From a structural point of view, this situation is very interesting. We are currently investigating selective guest inclusion, guest exchange, photophysical properties, and applicability of the pybenH system.

cln_elements.content: Synthetic procedure of the inclusion compounds is similar to that reported previously. To a methanol solution (200 mL) in which NiCl2·6H2O (0.18 g, 0.76 mmol) was suspended was added KSCN (0.15 g, 1.54 mmol) with vigorous stirring. After the precipitated KCl was filtered off, pybenH (0.30 g, 1.51 mmol) was dissolved. The solution was left for 24 h at room temperature, and 4,4′-dibromobiphenyl was then added to the solution. Green crystals of inclusion compound 1 were obtained after slow evaporation of the solvent over a period of a week at room temperature. The crystals are insoluble in common organic solvents, such as dichloromethane, acetone, and hexane, but soluble in hot methanol, DMF, and DMSO.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthetic procedure of the inclusion compounds is similar to that reported previously. To a methanol solution (200 mL) in which NiCl2⋅6H2O (0.18 g, 0.76 mmol) was suspended was added KSCN (0.15 g, 1.54 mmol) with vigorous stirring. After the precipitated KCl was filtered off, pybenH (0.30 g, 1.51 mmol) was dissolved. The solution was left for 24 h at room temperature, and 4,4'-dibromobiphenyl was then added to the solution. Green crystals of inclusion compound 1 were obtained after slow evaporation of the solvent over a period of a week at room temperature. The crystals are insoluble in common organic solvents, such as dichloromethane, acetone, and hexane, but soluble in hot methanol, DMF, and DMSO.

other properties: soluble in hot methanol, DMF, DMSO

The volume of the guests (V guest) was calculated using the X-ray structure data.

Packing coefficient = {(n × V guest)/(V void)}, where n = the number of the guests per unit cell.
